newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila shares end up for the 6th straight session.
newsitem.headline: Manila shares end up for the 6th straight session.

text.p: Philippine stocks settled with modest gains on Monday amid light trading as foreign investors continued to be sidelined by a dearth of positive news and the high interest rates scenario, traders said.
"We were in a tight range. People were just bargain-hunting on selective issues and those with short-term gains were selling," said Teresa Lee, vice-president at Asiamerit Securities.
The main index closed higher for the sixth consecutive session. It rose 3.89 points, or 0.15 percent, to 2,639.53 points.
"The attention was just on selected stocks, on concept plays or those issues with stories to tell," said Fitz Aclan, assistant vice-president for domestic sales at Orion-Squire Capital.
Traders said secondary issues made gains during the session such as Belle Corp, SM Prime Holdings and Waterfront Philippines Inc.
"Some punters were also playing on small floats," said Nathan Lozada, assistant vice-president at Paribas Asia Equity.
Turnover was light at 1.62 billion pesos, although improved from the previous session's 1.42 billion.

"The volumes do not indicate a clear trend. I expect the market to be moving in a tight range unless we see higher-than-expected inflation figures for July," said Raul Ruiz, vice-president at Sun Hung Kai Securities.
Inflation figures are released on the fifth of each month.
